ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Arabic alphabet, basic conversational skills, basic reading and speaking skills. I feel that I have learned quite a lot of Arabic for a beginning course of one semester.
Introduction to Arabic, vocabulary, writing in Arabic, speaking, and a little bit of grammar.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Aziz helps us move forward at a quick pace in our learning take in a lot of material effectively in a short amount of time. he provides many opportunities for student success and makes himself available for any questions.
Weaknesses: it would be helpful to add more student engagement to the course, more opportunities to talk with our fellow classmates and practice what we are learning in class (especially the vocabulary) + interact with the language in additional mediums. additionally, while I understand that the course closely follows a textbook curriculum, at some points I felt that it would have been helpful to learn in different categories (for example, we learned the colors green and black and only learned the rest of the colors a few months later)
It was a great introduction. I would only want more speaking practice in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would certainly recommend this course to anyone looking to start out learning Arabic. It is important to understand that the course is structured in such a way that you could put in very little work or a very lot of work, but since a lot of the learning happens outside of class time, the amount of effort put in outside of class is a lot of what impacts success in the class
Yes, if a student has no exposure to Arabic, they should take this course.
